text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Purpose – Simpliﬁed and shortened for clarity, and to use standard language.
IRM 4.22.5.1.1, Background – Added a new subsection to describe the internal control framework in the required format. Incorporates content previously located in 4.22.5.2.
IRM 4.22.5.1.3, Roles and Responsibilities – Added a new subsection to describe the internal control framework in the required format. Incorporates content previously located in 4.22.5.3.2.
IRM 4.22.5.1.4, Program Management – Added a new subsection to describe the internal control framework in the required format.
4.22.5.2, Background – Deleted subsection and moved all content to subsection 4.22.5.1.1, except for language detailing the replacement of TCMP examinations because it is no longer relevant.
4.22.5.3, Program Responsibility – Deleted Subsection. Content moved into subsection 4.22.5.1.
Headquarters – Deleted Subsection and moved content into subsection
4.22.5.2(2) – Added a paragraph and subsequent alpha list to update and more accurately describe the NRP examination process.
4.22.5.2.2(1) – Added information about the NRP Case Tracking System, and instructions for the NRP Coordinator regarding discrepancies between on-line systems as well as any local reports.
4.22.5.2.2(3) – Revised to identify the NRP Office as the point of contact for identiﬁed discrepancies instead of the NRP Coordinator and included a link.
4.22.5.2.3, Processing of NRP Returns – Added “NRP” to the title.
4.22.5.3(4) – The exhibit mentioned has been deleted. Users are now directed to a separate IRM obtain information about requesting an exclusion of NRP returns.
4.22.5.3(8) – Updated instructions to direct the NRP Coordinator’s review for the presence of a Partnership Investor Control File code and included a link to the TEFRA web page.
– Removed instructions regarding a six-month time frame.
4.22.5.4.5(1) – Removed “see Exhibit 4.22.5-2” because exhibit is no longer relevant and has been deleted from the IRM.
4.22.5.5.2(2) – Content of this paragraph and subsequent alpha list was previously incorporated in subsection 4.22.5.8.5.1(5) and reorganized here for relevancy and order.
Examples of Items to Consider When Evaluating NRP In-Process Cases – been deleted and content moved to a new subsection 4.22.5.8.2.
– Added a sentence to deﬁne a “new” employee.
4.22.5.6.2, Examples of Items to Consider when Evaluating NRP In-Process Cases – The content of this new subsection was previously incorporated in subsection 4.22.5.7.2.1 and moved here for order.
– This paragraph gives instructions to PAS reviewers and their managers regarding the for NRP training. It was formerly IRM 4.22.5.8.5(1) and moved here to a more relevant
4.22.5.6.5.1(5) – Content of this paragraph and subsequent alpha list have been reorganized to IRM 4.22.5.7.2(2) for relevancy and order.

Exhibit 4.22.5-1, Requesting Exclusion of NRP Returns (Form 4981) – Removed exhibit from the IRM and reorganized relevant content to various subsections. Added a new subsection 4.22.5.10 to direct users to further information regarding requesting an exclusion from NRP examination which eliminates the need for this exhibit.
4.22.5-2, NRP 1040 Group Manager Closed Case Review Checksheet – Deleted this exhibit the IRM because the content is outdated and no longer relevant.
Throughout this IRM section, editorial changes were made to add clarity, correct punctuation, and to update or add citations and references.
This IRM is to be used by SB/SE Cincinnati Campus Compliance Operations (CCCO) employees involved with the National Research Program.
Erik Ogilvie, Chief, National Research Program
Table of Contents
) Purpose: This IRM section provides guidance for conducting National Research Program (NRP) examinations of Form
NRP key case income tax returns as it relates to (CCCO) Cincinnati Campus Compliance erations. (

) Audience: The following IRS employees who participate in a National Research Program (NRP) individual income tax study are: • Campus Examination Managers • Team Leads • Examiners • Reviewers • NRP Staff (
) Policy Owner: Director, Knowledge Development and Application under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) is the policy owner. (
) Program Owner: NRP is the program office responsible for the oversight of the NRP studies. (
) For information about the National Research Program, visit the NRP at: https://nrp.web.irs.gov. (
) The following explains the NRP process as it pertains to Campus activities at the Cincinnati Campus Compliance Operations. (

) NRP examinations enable the Service to determine what key areas of pliance to address and what treatments to apply to maximize the use of its limited resources. As the Service’s ability to detect noncompliance audits become less effective and compliant taxpayers continue to be by unnecessary audits. (

) The NRP approach to measuring reporting compliance balances research quality, efficiency and taxpayer burden. NRP uses a hybrid of options for dating return information that maximizes use of data available to the IRS to the extent possible, minimizes taxpayer burden while collecting data. (
) Examination guidelines have been established for conducting NRP campus examinations. The returns selected for campus examinations were classiﬁed following the guidelines in the NRP IRM
) By law, the Service has the authority to conduct examinations under Title Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F – Procedure and Administration, Chapter
, Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title, Subchapter A, and Inspection, which includes, but is not limited to, the following IRC • IRC
, Examination of books and witnesses • IRC
, Time and place of examination Note: Additional information related to conducting examinations is contained in CFR
, Statement of Procedural Regulations. (
) Under the Reform and Restructuring Act of
(RRA ’
), Congress mandated the IRS to deliver service to taxpayers at a new and much higher level of performance in the most cost-effective and least burdensome Internal Revenue Manual
Audience: The following IRS employees who participate in a National Research Program (NRP) individual income tax study are:
The following explains the NRP process as it pertains to Campus Examination activities at the Cincinnati Campus Compliance Operations.
Note: Additional information related to conducting examinations is contained in 26 CFR 601.105, Statement of Procedural Regulations.
National Research Program possible. Data from NRP examinations enable the IRS to operate as a more efficient and effective tax administration organization. (
) The Director of Campus Compliance Operations in the designated Campus has overall responsibility for NRP Campus examinations. (
) The Operations Manager, Examination (OME) has overall responsibility for NRP program within their respective department. (
) The Department Managers delegate the responsibilities of the Campus NRP Coordinator to an appropriate person. (

) The Campus NRP Coordinator will coordinate and control the receipt and signment of NRP returns to groups. They approve transfer of cases and second line authority for approval/disapproval of exclusion requests. (
) The Inventory Control Manager is responsible for monitoring NRP inventory throughout the process. They monitor and report the status of the campus program. (

) The Group Manager is responsible for NRP cases within their team, the timely and priority assignment of NRP returns, counseling examiners on the scope and high quality requirements (see Auditing Standards in IRM
and the scope and depth of NRP examinations in IRM

). They are responsible for maintaining a workﬂow throughout the entire nation cycle that will ensure timely completion. This will require NRP See Training requirements on NRP training website and IRM
graphs (
) and (
) The Team Lead, in conjunction with the OME, are responsible for ensuring examiners’ compliance with Auditing Standards found in IRM
and scope and depth of NRP examination requirements found in IRM

They are responsible for the quality of the ﬁnal review of NRP cases. They also responsible for appointing local NRP reviewers. These reviewers must familiar with all the technical aspects of NRP and informing the OME of any problems encountered. (
) The Campus Exam Technicians assigned NRP cases must be thoroughly familiar with the NRP program procedures. This will require NRP training NRP training website and IRM
paragraphs (
) and (

)). A Headquarters Policy Analyst is assigned to the program to facilitate policy related issues, ensure NRP requirements are met and assist with tion between the Campus Compliance Examination Officials and the NRP Office. (

) Effective management of the NRP study is achieved by training the NRP managers and examiners. This ensures that quality examinations are conducted and the IRS gets good data. • Only examiners who complete NRP training will work NRP cases. • The number of NRP examiners appointed will be sufficient to handle NRP workload. (
) Qualiﬁed examiners at appropriate grade levels will be assigned NRP Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A deﬁned term applicable to individual income tax Report Generation Software (RGS) is a comprehensive used to perform a variety of audit and review tasks. In tax, penalties and interest on the examination report, RGS spondence, work papers and case closing documents. (

) Following is a list of acronyms relating to case building: a. AIMS - Audit Information Management System b. CTS - Case-Tracking System c. CDW - Compliance Data Warehouse d. DIF - Discriminant Function e. EIC - Earned Income Credit f. EOAD - Examination Operational Automation g. EQRS - Embedded Quality Review System h. ERCS - Examination Returns Control System i. LB&I - Large Business and International Division j. NRP - National Research Program k. PSP - Planning and Special Programs l. QRDB - Quality Review Data Base m. RGS - Report Generation Software n. SAC - Special Agent in Charge o. SB/SE - Small Business and Self Employed Division p. TCMP - Taxpayer Compliance Measurement Program q. TE/GE - Tax Exempt and Government Entities Division

Report Generation Software (RGS) is a comprehensive software used to perform a variety of audit and review tasks. In addition to tax, penalties and interest on the examination report, RGS generates spondence, work papers and case closing documents. (

) Following is a list of acronyms relating to case building: a. AIMS - Audit Information Management System b. CTS - Case-Tracking System c. CDW - Compliance Data Warehouse d. DIF - Discriminant Function e. EIC - Earned Income Credit f. EOAD - Examination Operational Automation Database g. EQRS - Embedded Quality Review System h. , Examination of NRP Returns (

) Campus Compliance Operations Examination officials must ensure that examinations are completed promptly. The Group Manager plays the role in ensuring that examinations are initiated and completed promptly sacriﬁcing quality. (

) The NRP examination process follows the normal examination process to extent possible. By adhering to normal examination processes and NRP minimizes the burden to both the taxpayer and examiner while still capturing the necessary data. Each NRP study consists of the following processes for a single tax year. a. Sample Selection - Each NRP study selects a statistically valid, random sample of returns. Data from the sampled returns produce a of data that is representative of the study population from which the returns were selected. With appropriate weighting, the results from sample returns can be used to develop estimates for the study tion. b. Case Building - Refer to IRM
NRP Case Building, for detailed formation about the NRP Case Building process. c. Classiﬁcation - Refer to IRM
Classiﬁcation of NRP Returns, for detailed information about the NRP Classiﬁcation process.

4.22.5.2 (04-15-2020) NRP Examination Process

a. Sample Selection - Each NRP study selects a statistically valid, random sample of returns. Data from the sampled returns produce a set of data that is representative of the study population from which the returns were selected. With appropriate weighting, the results from the sample returns can be used to develop estimates for the study popula- tion. b. Case Building - Refer to IRM
NRP Case Building, for detailed in- formation about the NRP Case Building process. c. Classiﬁcation - Refer to IRM

National Research Program d. Examination - Except as otherwise speciﬁed in IRM
of NRP Returns, existing examination processes and procedures are be followed for NRP cases. e. Data Transmission - Refer to IRM
Examination of NRP for detailed information about the NRP Data Transmission process. (

) To facilitate continued improvements to NRP studies and processes, the staff will communicate with the Campus Headquarters Policy Analyst in nation with the NRP Coordinators, to solicit feedback and insights on each study. These discussions should include any recommended changes for studies, taxpayer reactions to the program and ways of accomplishing Mission with reduced taxpayer examination burden. (

) The NRP Office will coordinate with designated SBSE Campus officials NRP Coordinator prior to the shipment of any NRP cases for a study year. Returns Physical and electronic NRP case ﬁles will be built by the NRP case team in accordance with IRM
As outlined in IRM

, all items be included in the electronic RGS case ﬁle. The physical NRP case folder consist of only a copy of the selected tax return or transcript, if the return not e-ﬁled, as well as any Amended Return ﬁled, Correspondence by the taxpayer, and an NRP Case Stuffer, if applicable. The electronic Case ﬁle will be forwarded to the applicable Campus RGS group. The NRP case folders will be delivered to the NRP Coordinator for veriﬁcation. (

) Upon receipt of an NRP case ﬁle(s), the NRP Coordinator immediately that the shipment is complete and agrees with the accompanying list. If the shipment is incomplete, the NRP Coordinator must contact the Office to resolve any missing or extra cases. (

) After veriﬁcation, the original and one copy of the transmittal lists must be signed and dated on each page by the NRP Coordinator. Receipt of must be acknowledged within three workdays after receipt in the Operation. Receipt acknowledgment is to be returned to the Case Building Team. (

) Criminal Investigation (CI) receives copies of transmittal lists from the Building Team and will notify the NRP Coordinator within ten workdays of examination that is to be coordinated. Any case that CI places controls on any point during the NRP process will be immediately transferred to the (See transfer procedures in IRM

application. (
) If any discrepancies are identiﬁed, contact the NRP office NRP office. (
) NRP returns are processed under existing procedures as found in IRM unless otherwise speciﬁed herein. If conﬂicts arise with existing examination guidelines, NRP guidelines will take precedence. (
) SBSE Campus Analysts will work with Management to develop a case ment strategy that ensures timely completion of all assigned NRP cases for study year. (
) NRP Coordinators should promptly assign NRP case ﬁles to the NRP Exam Groups according to the previously decided case assignment strategy. (
) After receipt of the returns, NRP Exam Groups should promptly assign to the NRP examiner. NRP Exam Groups should initiate taxpayer contact quickly as possible. (
) NRP managers and examiners will receive NRP training to ensure quality aminations are conducted, correct and complete NRP examination record are entered. (
) NRP returns must only be assigned to examiners that have completed the plicable NRP training. Examiners and Managers with open or assigned must complete the training course once every
months. (
) NRP selections are not a basis for reopening a previously examined return. (

) The NRP Coordinator should review the AMDISA print to verify the a Partnership Investor Control File (PICF) code. The PCIF code indicates examination of a ﬂow-through entity with potential adjustments to the NRP case. If the PICF code exists, please use the TEFRA web page at: http:// tefra.web.irs.gov/m
f_contact.asp to coordinate the disposition of the (
) All returns selected as part of the NRP sample will be completed according NRP guidelines. (
) Examinations must be initiated on all NRP returns. There will be no surveys before or after assignment. Campus (
) An exclusion should be requested if any of the following conditions apply as outlined in IRM
, Exclusions (from NRP examination). (
) There are several systemic exclusions that will preclude certain taxpayers the NRP sample. This includes taxpayers who were audited during the prior
NRP Studies (TYs
and

An exclusion should be requested if any of the following conditions apply as outlined in IRM 4.22.4.3.6, Exclusions (from NRP examination).
National Research Program (
) If indications of fraud are discovered during the examination of an NRP or related return, referrals should be made in accordance with IRM

referral must be labeled as an NRP case. If the Campus/Exam Fraud nator accepts the referral and the case cannot be completed with a estimate of adjustment results, a request for exclusion should be submitted. (
) NRP cases having related returns are given priority in examination to ensure timely completion. When establishing an AIMS control for a related return up, Source Code
is to be used. (

) The NRP Coordinator should review the AMDISA print to verify the presence a Partnership Investor Control File (PCIF) code. The PCIF code indicates examination of a ﬂow-through entity with potential adjustments to the NRP case. If the PICF code exists, please use the TEFRA web page at: web.irs.gov/m
f_contact.asp to coordinate the disposition of the case. (

) All situations or problems that arise which are not covered in this section should be brought to the attention of the NRP Coordinator for resolution with the appropriate HQ analyst, and the NRP Office. (

) At any point of the NRP Studies, the Campus, in coordination with the NRP Coordinator, will communicate comments on the study to the NRP Office. These comments should include any recommended changes for future taxpayer reaction and examiner burden. (

) NRP results will be used to develop the Discriminant Function (DIF) formula; therefore, it is essential that examinations be thorough. Effective DIF of must reﬂect the actual error patterns found on tax returns regardless of and must, to the extent possible, be free of any bias resulting from errors on the part of the examiner. (

) Examiners must use their professional judgment concerning the depth of amination required for any item on the tax return while bearing in mind the research nature of the examination. The depth can be the same as is used operational audits. Therefore, taxpayers are not held to a higher standard. Issues should be pursued to the depth necessary to reach a supportable clusion. a. Every classiﬁed item must be examined. b. Additional items may be examined with approval from the Team Lead accordance with established procedures. Such approval, when given, must be documented on the electronic workpapers contained in RGS. c. At a minimum, some inquiry or inspection of records or documents porting reported or possible underreported income, deductions and credits must be made. (

) The examiner must state on the workpapers what actions were taken to the requirements of the NRP Examination. a. Audit procedures and conclusions for each issue audited must be supported by written comments in the workpapers. This is necessary ensure that the statistical data gathered by NRP is accurate and complete. b. Examiners must describe what inquiry or inspection of records or documents was made to verify unreported income, deductions or
4.22 National Research Program (NRP)

If indications of fraud are discovered during the examination of an NRP or related return, referrals should be made in accordance with IRM 4.19.10.4. The referral must be labeled as an NRP case. If the Campus/Exam Fraud Coordi- nator accepts the referral and the case cannot be completed with a reasonable estimate of adjustment results, a request for exclusion should be submitted.

porting reported or possible underreported income, deductions and credits must be made. Any research a new address, as well as telephone number, must be documented on the electronic workpapers. If neither can be found, the case will be transferred to the appropriate Area Office NRP Coordinator. If a new address is located, the initial contact letter will be reissued, and the

) AIMS & the NRP Case Tracking System (CTS) will be updated accordingly all transfers. The RGS case will be transferred from the Campus Examination group to the applicable Area NRP Coordinator in PSP. The transfer package
National Research Program (NRP)

must be routed through the NRP Coordinator for review and update of control records. The NRP Coordinator should establish local procedures, with appro- priate management approval, for expediting transfers, both into and out of the area. (
) A completed Form

(Document Transmittal) with the NRP cycle clearly entered in the “Comments” section should be used to transfer NRP case ﬁles and any related data from Campus Exam to the Area NRP Coordinator. The Form
should be addressed to the attention of the Area NRP Coordinator in PSP. (
) Upon receipt of an NRP case ﬁle package, the Area NRP Coordinator must acknowledge receipt by updating the NRP Case Tracking System (CTS) and acknowledging the Form
The NRP Coordinator should review the
periodically to see if the “Acknowledgement Copy” of the Document Transmittal (Form
) has been received. If it has not been received, within
business days, follow-up action should be taken by contacting the NRP Coordinator to ensure transfer completion. (
) Transfers should be completed early in the NRP cycle as a convenience to receiving Area Office. (
) The cut-off for shipping an NRP case to an Area NRP Coordinator is the as exam procedures found in IRM

, Statute of Limitations, unless permission for a different period is obtained from the transferee Area NRP ordinator. It is important to start all examinations promptly to avoid transfers that may occur outside established time frames. (
) Formal discussions between transferor and transferee areas are strongly rec- ommended. This will eliminate questionable transfers. (
) If the Area Office NRP Coordinator does not acknowledge Form
within a reasonable time period, the Campus NRP Coordinator will contact the Area Office by telephone. (

Case will be reviewed by the NRP Coordinator for completeness of data ﬁelds. Cases that pass the Detroit Computing Center validation checks will be returned to the Team Lead and put in RGS status
for case closing actions.
Cases that pass the Detroit Computing Center validation checks will be returned to the Team Lead and put in RGS status 51 for case closing
) The NRP Coordinator will transmit data from the key NRP case to Detroit Computing Center (DCC) for validation check. (
) DCC will run validation of the data. Results of the validation process will annotated on the NRP Case Tracking System (CTS). (
) The NRP Coordinator will review the CTS. Cases that do not pass will be corrected and resubmitted by NRP Coordinator to DCC. This process will repeat until all validation checks are passed. (
) After all DCC validation checks are passed, the case will be updated to
and the NRP AIMS freeze code ‘
’ can be removed. The case can closed from the group using the existing case closing process. (

) The NRP Office and the Operating Division should evaluate enough NRP cases to ensure examiner compliance with examination requirements discussed in this IRM. Cases selected for evaluation will be representative those worked by Campus Exam. The evaluation will be completed during early months of the NRP examination cycle, but not before enough cases available for review so that the sample will include a representative mix of returns. This is necessary so that appropriate measures can be taken to improve quality if needed. (

) Regular case management evaluation procedures should be followed, including the NRP objectives listed below: a. Determine the timeliness of assignment, examination and review of returns, and whether the NRP Examination records were promptly submitted to the DCC. b. Determine that the examiners have complied with the Auditing found in IRM

The examiners must state in their workpapers actions were taken to fulﬁll the requirements of the NRP These workpapers, which include those items not otherwise on, should be general in nature, and tailored to the taxpayer’s examination. c. Determine whether the applicable NRP related case procedures followed.
(04-15-2020) Transmission of Electronic Data to Detroit Computing Center

After all DCC validation checks are passed, the case will be updated to status 51 and the NRP AIMS freeze code ‘3’ can be removed. The case can then be closed from the group using the existing case closing process.

Determine the timeliness of assignment, examination and review of NRP returns, and whether the NRP Examination records were promptly submitted to the DCC. Determine that the examiners have complied with the Auditing found in IRM

The examiners must state in their workpapers actions were taken to fulﬁll the requirements of the NRP examination. These workpapers, which include those items not otherwise commented on, should be general in nature, and tailored to the taxpayer’s individual examination. Determine whether the applicable NRP related case procedures were followed.
National Research Program (

) Campus Exam should establish sufficient monitoring procedures to control manage the program including in-process and closed case reviews. The Director, Campus Compliance Operations, should establish in-process review teams, consisting of Department Managers, Team Lead, and These teams are encouraged to conduct at least annual reviews until the completion of this project. ) Adequate records should be maintained on NRP cases reviewed with to the following information: a. Number of cases reviewed b. Number of cases accepted c. Number of cases awaiting review d. ) In-process reviews are critical in guaranteeing the highest quality of NRP cases. At a minimum, an evaluative in-process review is required on the case assigned each new NRP Examiner. A new NRP examiner is any examiner who has not completed an NRP Campus examination in the years. Compliance Operations Site 4.22.5
Operations Site
) In-process reviews are critical in guaranteeing the highest quality in all program cases. Completion of the in-process reviews will be to in the manner set forth below. (

) Reporting and control procedures: a. Prompt veriﬁcation and acknowledgment of NRP return packages the Case Building Team; b. Prompt assignment to examination units; c. Timely disposition and acknowledgment of transfer cases; d. Exclusion procedures are being followed and input by authorized personnel; e. Prompt reconciliation of control reports. (

) Completion of NRP Examinations: a. Timely assignment of cases to examiners; b. Prompt opening and continued priority treatment of NRP cases; c. Timely working of cases with correspondence, usually within
days receipt. (
) Timely processing of cases through Quality Review - Process Analysis (PAS). (

) Training a. Have all NRP Team Leads received formal NRP training to ensure quality examinations are conducted and that correct and complete Report data have been entered? b. Have all the examiners working NRP returns received formal NRP training? c. Are there sufficient NRP Examiners to handle the workload (

) Scope and Depth of Examinations: a. Determine thoroughness of audit; b. Determine whether inquiry was made for possible unreported income, deductions and credits; c. Determine whether adequate comments were made in workpapers; d. Determine whether adequate consideration was given to documentation. (

) Quality of NRP Examination Record: a. Review for technical correctness; b. Review for mathematical accuracy and completeness in entering and egorizing adjustments and accuracy of input to the EOAD ﬁelds; c. Review of procedural requirements. (
) Verify that trends in error patterns on the quality of the examinations and Examination Records are being transmitted periodically to NRP office. (

) To facilitate continued improvements of NRP cycles, the NRP Coordinator, in (

) coordination with the NRP Team Lead, should submit written comments on the Narrative Report survey cycle and should include any recommended changes for the upcoming Program Operations surveys.
